target: All spirits who cause us to break our samaya and lead us astray
Such miserable torment is difficult to endure,
And in the course of many lives throughout unnumbered ages,

This lineage prayer for the Tārā of Power was spoken by Chökyi Lodrö, who holds the name of an incarnation of Jamyang Khyentse, and written down by his student Tsewang Jorgyé, whose mind is rich in faith. May this bring virtue and excellence!
To all those who intend to pass into nirvāṇa
And act inappropriately in all kinds of ways.
Grant your blessings, I pray!

“It is like this: it would be possible, for instance, to quantify the merit gained by gathering a pile of jewels as large as Mount Meru, and making a gift of it, but the merit of [writing or encouraging others to write] this Sūtra of Boundless Life and Wisdom can not be calculated.
As for the main mantra, you are allowed to perform the activities if you recite the mantra 100,000 times multiplied by the amount of syllables of the mantra.
From the subtle, barely discernible
In the pure dharmakāya realm of unchanging awareness,
All that awaits the sentient beings of this degenerate age
And especially the Eight Great Close Sons—
Where suffering is so terribly hard to bear!
This gathering of the hundred and eight lotsawas,
In Bodhgaya they meet with twenty-five paṇḍitas,
From beginningless time in saṃsāra till now,
The lamp of beings, the torch of wisdom,
oṃ vajrakrodha mahābala hana daha paca vidhvaṃsaya jaṭilambodari ucchuṣma krodha hūṃ phaṭ ||
May these flames, offering-rays of five-coloured lights of wisdom,
In the infinite display of form that manifests out of the ground,
Banish the dense darkness of mind’s obscurations!
Lord of Dharma, you spontaneously accomplish twofold benefit—
Presides the enlightened one, the lord of wisdom and longevity, Amitāyus,
I pray: do not pass but remain upon the vajra throne!
And, through enduring hardships while cultivating devotion and compassion
Nirmanakāya Padmākara: homage to you!
Dark blue in colour, with three heads, six hands,
Grant it here in the just same way, we pray!
Vajrakaumārī, Kulaṃdarī,
